hints_html:
There are several ways to compute the inverse of a matrix. Which ones are you familiar with?

One way to obtain the inverse of a matrix is to row-reduce the augmented matrix [A I]. Here I is the 3x3 identity matrix.
hints_latex:
There are several ways to compute the inverse of a matrix. Which ones
are you familiar with?

One way to obtain the inverse of a matrix is to row-reduce the augmented
matrix {[}\emph{A} \textbar{} \emph{I}{]}. Here \emph{I} is the
\emph{3x3} identity matrix.
hints_raw:
There are several ways to compute the inverse of a matrix. Which ones are you familiar with?
One way to obtain the inverse of a matrix is to row-reduce the augmented matrix [''A'' | ''I'']. Here ''I'' is the ''3x3'' identity matrix.
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
When t = 0, the matrix A is

\[\begin{aligned} A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 4 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

One way to obtain the inverse of a matrix is to row-reduce the augmented matrix [AI]. Let’s proceed with this method.

\[\begin{aligned} \left[A|I\right] =\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 3 & 4 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 2 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Perform L2 \(\rightarrow\) L2-L1 and L3 \(\rightarrow\) L3-(2/3)L1

\[\begin{aligned} \sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2/3 & -1 & -2/3 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Perform L3 \(\rightarrow\) 3L3

\[\begin{aligned} \sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & -3 & -2 & 0 & 3 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Perform L3 \(\rightarrow\) L3-L2

\[\begin{aligned} \sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 3 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Perform L3 \(\rightarrow\) (-1)L3

\[\begin{aligned} \sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Perform L1 \(\rightarrow\) L1-L2 and L2 \(\rightarrow\) L2+2L3

\[\begin{aligned} \sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 3 & 0 & 5 & 2 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 & 1 & 3 & -6 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Perform L1 \(\rightarrow\) L1-5L3

\[\begin{aligned} \sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 3 & 0 & 0 & -3 & -6 & 15 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 & 1 & 3 & -6 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Perform L1 \(\rightarrow\) (1/3)L1 and L2 \(\rightarrow\) (1/2)L2

\[\begin{aligned} \sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & 1/2 & 3/2 & -3 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

And we can conclude that

\[\begin{aligned} A^{-1} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1 & -2 & 5 \\ 1/2 & 3/2 & -3 \\ 1 & 1 & -3 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
When ''t'' = 0, the matrix ''A'' is
:<math>
A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 \\
3 & 4 & 1 \\
2 & 2 & 1
\end{array}\right]
</math>

One way to obtain the inverse of a matrix is to row-reduce the augmented matrix [A|I]. Let's proceed with this method.

:<math>
\left[A|I\right] =\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
3 & 4 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
2 & 2 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]
</math>
Perform L<sub>2</sub> &rarr; L<sub>2</sub>-L<sub>1</sub> and L<sub>3</sub> &rarr; L<sub>3</sub>-(2/3)L<sub>1</sub>
:<math>
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 2/3 & -1 & -2/3 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]
</math>
Perform L<sub>3</sub> &rarr; 3L<sub>3</sub>
:<math>
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -3 & -2 & 0 & 3
\end{array}\right]
</math>
Perform L<sub>3</sub> &rarr; L<sub>3</sub>-L<sub>2</sub>
:<math>
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 3
\end{array}\right]
</math>
Perform L<sub>3</sub> &rarr; (-1)L<sub>3</sub>
:<math>
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]
</math>
Perform L<sub>1</sub> &rarr; L<sub>1</sub>-L<sub>2</sub> and L<sub>2</sub> &rarr; L<sub>2</sub>+2L<sub>3</sub>
:<math>
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 0 & 5 & 2 & -1 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & 0 & 1 & 3 & -6 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]
</math>
Perform L<sub>1</sub> &rarr; L<sub>1</sub>-5L<sub>3</sub>
:<math>
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 0 & 0 & -3 & -6 & 15 \\
0 & 2 & 0 & 1 & 3 & -6 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]
</math>
Perform L<sub>1</sub> &rarr; (1/3)L<sub>1</sub> and L<sub>2</sub> &rarr; (1/2)L<sub>2</sub>
:<math>
\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2 & 5 \\
0 & 1 & 0 & 1/2 & 3/2 & -3 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]
</math>

And we can conclude that
:<math>
A^{-1} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & -2 & 5 \\
1/2 & 3/2 & -3 \\
1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]
</math>
statement_html:
Compute A-1 when t = 0, where

\[\begin{aligned} A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 2 & t+3 \\ 3 & 4 & t+1 \\ 2 & 2 & t+1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Compute ''A''<sup>-1</sup> when ''t'' = 0, where
:<math>
A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 2 & t+3 \\
3 & 4 & t+1 \\
2 & 2 & t+1
\end{array}\right]
</math>
